text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SABAH
- Coalition partners plan to form a three-way election alliance by joining with the far-rightist Grand Unity Party.
- Economists estimate the cost of an election as 500 trillion lira and predict a jump in the inflation rate.
MILLIYET
- Former trade minister Yalim Erez, from the conservative wing of the coalition, is sacked by party executive board for his criticism of coalition with Islamists.
- A report revealed by Credit Risk International says Turkey's economic indicators are not bad but that politicians put the country at risk.
HURRIYET
- Leading members of True Path Party coalition partner at odds with party leader Tansu Ciller on a possible election alliance with the Islamists.
- Military says it has given enough warnings to the government on a proposed anti-Islamist crackdown and will now keep silent and monitor political developments.
YENI YUZYIL
- Islamists propose going straight to elections to avoid a tricky handover of power to Ciller.
- First court hearing in a seven-month-old security scandal begins in Istanbul.
RADIKAL
- The minimum civil servant salary will 45 million lira if planned new regulations are made effective
- A promotion campaign in 30 countries sponsored by the tourism ministry has begun to bear fruit. The number of holidaymakers coming to Turkey rose by 15.5 percent in the first third of 1997.
DUNYA
- The business world does not want early elections.
- Domestic gas cannister prices rose by seven per cent.
ZAMAN
- Three former education ministers have criticised military-inspired efforts to introduce eight years of uninterrupted compulsory education.
CUMHURIYET
- Relatives of suspects at security scandal trial attack journalists.
